Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Evaluating the Risks, Tradeoffs and Opportunities of Entrepreneurial Startups In Different Regions Using Gamification

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
While successful entrepreneurship contributes to job creation, many unanswered questions remain about why so many new start-ups fail. The research develops and evaluates a novel educational model to increase the likelihood of entrepreneurial success and ability to operate in different regional innovative ecosystems. Through a computer simulation game or gamulation, entrepreneurs can experiment with different organizational structures, hiring decisions, strategy development, and use of a variety of institutional supports. The research will examine how entrepreneurial organizations may function when confronting different regional dynamics. Gamulation play allows entrepreneurs to experiment in a safe environment with their start-up proposals, while also providing data with which to generate recommendations for how entrepreneurs should approach different challenges within and between regions. The results of this project contribute understanding to why similar start-ups vary in performance; how regional attributes affect these outcomes; and what strategies firms may use to increase the likelihood of survival and growth.

This project designs a user friendly, novel game design for engaging entrepreneurship students and provides for experimentation with different decisions in new firm formation and scale up. Students will gain a better understanding of what constitutes successful entrepreneurial firm development. The gamulation simulates different entrepreneurial environments and is tailored to different entrepreneurs, industries, and regions. The gamulation further serves as a platform for collecting data about entrepreneurial decisions and generates real-time data on how decisions that entrepreneurs make in their regional and economic context impact their firm?s success.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To deliver a state-of-the-art gaming + simulation or gamulationTM experience to those who want to learn about being a more effective entrepreneur. Players will have an engaging, lifelike experience within a simulated environment that will expose them to the best practices identified in current leadership and entrepreneurship literature, to improve their knowledge and to increase their chances at real life entrepreneurship. The gameplay will involve starting a high-technology start-up, and founders will be faced with navigating the roles, responsibilities, challenges, and dilemmas that are involved with starting a new high-tech business in one of 11 specific regions/cities around the United States.

To design this educational learning tool, we examined the research literature and metadata on successful and unsuccessful entrepreneurial high-tech start-ups, as well as the leadership development literature. We also interviewed entrepreneurs who had started firms to examine the nature of the challenges they faced in different phases of firm development.

The five phases of gamulation educational program play unfolded in the following order; introduction/company setup, pre-revenue, early revenue, “valley of death”, and having a sustainable business. These phases follow the normative phases for a new start-up company based on the research and practice literature in entrepreneurship. 

We then used this research as a basis for building the narrative for gamulation play, and the challenges entrepreneurs typically face with new start-ups, the learning objectives, as well as the criteria we used to evaluate the player’s success in navigating through the phases of firm development. In addition, we added specific, real world experiences informed by entrepreneurs to increase levels of engagement.

We included the 11 different regions for the same start-up firm because research evidence indicates that variations in regional characteristics matter to whether the same firm will be successful or not. The 11 regional characteristics used were total VC investment, total VC deals, mean VC investment, average SBA loan, rate of new entrepreneurs, startup density, corporate tax rate, state business tax climate, cost of living, cost of housing, available qualified workforce, and the average salary of qualified workforce.

Players work through specific challenges and decisions in each phase, which are based on the entrepreneurial research literature. Responses to these challenges are linked to research findings that have indicated what works and doesn’t work in terms of firm success for each phase of a firm’s development.Players are also judged based on four key metrics commonly used in business to judge the success of organizations, including cash flow, stakeholder satisfaction, customer satisfaction and employee satisfaction.

Players decisions are also evaluated based on 4 positive motivational factors that are derived from the responses players provide in terms of how they address challenges. These include their efficacy or confidence, optimism, resiliency, and hopefulness. Feedback reports are provided to each player after completing their final decisions.

Another facet of this educational tool is the inclusion of a mentoring function. The mentoring function provides feedback and guidance to players as they navigate through the various phases of firm development. The advice provided by the mentoring function is based on the findings in the entrepreneurial and leadership development research literature, as well as what we learned from interviewing successful entrepreneurs.

In sum, this first-generation single player educational program will be used in undergraduate, graduate and external training programs focused on developing successful entrepreneurs, using a highly interactive format, which we can continuously update with new data from the 11 regions, challenges, and decisions.  In the next revision, we will be introducing a multi-player format with new challenges and opportunities for players to navigate through in growing their firms, as well as continuing to advance the complexity of the real-world data that drives the gamulation experience.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2019
Modified by: Bruce Avolio
